content:
Everyone who's interested in authoring and reviewing sections in the restructure of the async book, what areas are you interested in? We can use the structure proposal as a template (it may change a bit though - not fully reviewed).

Ping @Alice Ryhl @Lee Bernick @Esteban KÃ¼ber

The things that seem most interesting to write about are:

  • Sending and sharing data between tasks
  • Synchronizing data across tasks
  • Combinators for non-sequential control flow
  • Cancelling futures by dropping them
  • The poll contract
  • Nested futures and pin projection

I've already written a bunch on "Beware of blocking code" as well

It's probably best if somebody else writes the section on runtime choice, since I'm not exactly neutral on this point.

I have work in progress docs for:

- The `Future` trait
- The `async/await` syntax
- Combinators for non-sequential control flow (just a little)
- Beware of blocking code
- Multithreaded vs singlethreaded

My weakest side is IO (I work on Fuchsia where I've used much more of our custom IPC than File IO/networking).
Happy to review anything.
If you have work-in-progress for "beware of blocking code", you may want to compare with https://ryhl.io/blog/async-what-is-blocking/
Awesome. Yup, that looks like the main overlap here.
Feel free to steal pieces from my blog post if they are useful.
Thanks! Some stuff there that's new to me, great.
